user_message:
<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 1.2 is: Language extensions should not be used.
You should report only when the code uses any language compiler extensions that are explicitly stated as an extension in compiler documentations.
</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of OS_SocketConnect:
```c
int32 OS_SocketConnect(osal_id_t sock_id, const OS_SockAddr_t *Addr, int32 Timeout)
{
    OS_stream_internal_record_t *stream;
    OS_object_token_t            token;
    int32                        return_code;

    /* Check Parameters */
    OS_CHECK_POINTER(Addr);

    return_code = OS_ObjectIdGetById(OS_LOCK_MODE_EXCLUSIVE, LOCAL_OBJID_TYPE, sock_id, &token);
    if (return_code == OS_SUCCESS)
    {
        stream = OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET(OS_stream_table, token);

        if (stream->socket_domain == OS_SocketDomain_INVALID)
        {
            return_code = OS_ERR_INCORRECT_OBJ_TYPE;
        }
        else if (stream->socket_type == OS_SocketType_STREAM && (stream->stream_state & OS_STREAM_STATE_CONNECTED) != 0)
        {
            /* Stream socket must not be connected */
            return_code = OS_ERR_INCORRECT_OBJ_STATE;
        }
        else
        {
            return_code = OS_SocketConnect_Impl(&token, Addr, Timeout);

            if (return_code == OS_SUCCESS)
            {
                stream->stream_state |= OS_STREAM_STATE_CONNECTED | OS_STREAM_STATE_READABLE | OS_STREAM_STATE_WRITABLE;
            }
        }

        OS_ObjectIdRelease(&token);
    }

    return return_code;
}
```
</target_code>
<additional code>Here are the definitions of symbols that are related to the target function OS_SocketConnect:
#define OS_CHECK_POINTER(ptr) BUGCHECK((ptr)!=NULL,OS_INVALID_POINTER)
...
int32 OS_ObjectIdGetById(OS_lock_mode_t lock_mode, osal_objtype_t idtype, osal_id_t id, OS_object_token_t *token)
{
    int32 return_code;

    return_code = OS_ObjectIdTransactionInit(lock_mode, idtype, token);
    if (return_code != OS_SUCCESS)
    {
        return return_code;
    }

    return_code = OS_ObjectIdToArrayIndex(idtype, id, &token->obj_idx);
    if (return_code == OS_SUCCESS)
    {
        token->obj_id = id;

        /*
         * The "ConvertToken" routine will return with the global lock
         * in a state appropriate for returning to the caller, as indicated
         * by the "check_mode" parameter.
         *
         * Note If this operation fails, then it always unlocks the global for
         * all check_mode's other than NONE.
         */
        return_code = OS_ObjectIdConvertToken(token);
    }

    if (return_code != OS_SUCCESS)
    {
        OS_ObjectIdTransactionCancel(token);
    }

    return return_code;
}
...
#define OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET(tbl, tok) (&tbl[OS_ObjectIndexFromToken(&(tok))])
...
extern OS_stream_internal_record_t OS_stream_table[OS_MAX_NUM_OPEN_FILES]
...
typedef struct
{
    char   stream_name[OS_MAX_PATH_LEN];
    uint8  socket_domain;
    uint8  socket_type;
    uint16 stream_state;
} OS_stream_internal_record_t
...
typedef struct OS_object_token OS_object_token_t
...
int32 OS_SocketConnect_Impl(const OS_object_token_t *token, const OS_SockAddr_t *Addr, int32 timeout)
{
    int32                           return_code;
    int                             os_status;
    int                             sockopt;
    socklen_t                       slen;
    uint32                          operation;
    const struct sockaddr *         sa;
    OS_impl_file_internal_record_t *impl;

    impl = OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET(OS_impl_filehandle_table, *token);

    sa = (const struct sockaddr *)&Addr->AddrData;
    switch (sa->sa_family)
    {
        case AF_INET:
            slen = sizeof(struct sockaddr_in);
            break;
#ifdef OS_NETWORK_SUPPORTS_IPV6
        case AF_INET6:
            slen = sizeof(struct sockaddr_in6);
            break;
#endif
        default:
            slen = 0;
            break;
    }

    if (slen != Addr->ActualLength)
    {
        return_code = OS_ERR_BAD_ADDRESS;
    }
    else
    {
        return_code = OS_SUCCESS;
        os_status   = connect(impl->fd, sa, slen);
        if (os_status < 0)
        {
            if (errno != EINPROGRESS)
            {
                OS_DEBUG("connect: %s\n", strerror(errno));
                return_code = OS_ERROR;
            }
            else
            {
                /*
                 * If the socket was created in nonblocking mode (O_NONBLOCK flag) then the connect
                 * runs in the background and connect() returns EINPROGRESS.  In this case we still
                 * want to provide the "normal" (blocking) semantics to the calling app, such that
                 * when OS_SocketConnect() returns, the socket is ready for use.
                 *
                 * To provide consistent behavior to calling apps, this does a select() to wait
                 * for the socket to become writable, meaning that the remote side is connected.
                 *
                 * An important point here is that the calling app can control the timeout.  If the
                 * normal/blocking connect() was used, the OS/IP stack controls the timeout, and it
                 * can be quite long.
                 */
                operation = OS_STREAM_STATE_WRITABLE;
                if (impl->selectable)
                {
                    return_code = OS_SelectSingle_Impl(token, &operation, timeout);
                }
                if (return_code == OS_SUCCESS)
                {
                    if ((operation & OS_STREAM_STATE_WRITABLE) == 0)
                    {
                        return_code = OS_ERROR_TIMEOUT;
                    }
                    else
                    {
                        /*
                         * The SO_ERROR socket flag should also read back zero.
                         * If not zero, something went wrong during connect
                         */
                        sockopt   = 0;
                        slen      = sizeof(sockopt);
                        os_status = getsockopt(impl->fd, SOL_SOCKET, SO_ERROR, &sockopt, &slen);
                        if (os_status < 0 || sockopt != 0)
                        {
                            return_code = OS_ERROR;
                        }
                    }
                }
            }
        }
    }
    return return_code;
}
...
void OS_ObjectIdRelease(OS_object_token_t *token)
{
    OS_ObjectIdTransactionFinish(token, NULL);
}
...
typedef struct
{
    size_t            ActualLength; /**< @brief Length of the actual address data */
    OS_SockAddrData_t AddrData;     /**< @brief Abstract Address data */
} OS_SockAddr_t
...
typedef uint32 osal_id_t
...
typedef int32_t   int32
...
#define OS_SUCCESS (0)
...
#define OS_ERR_INCORRECT_OBJ_TYPE (-36)
...
#define OS_ERR_INCORRECT_OBJ_STATE (-35)
</additional code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
explanation: I examined the provided function and the related definitions for signs of compiler-specific language extensions that are explicitly documented as extensions (for example: __attribute__, __extension__, __asm__/asm, GCC statement-expressions ({ ... }), typeof, nested functions, label-as-values, inline assembly, compiler builtins like __builtin_*, or other nonstandard keywords). None of those constructs are present. The code uses standard C language constructs, macros, typedefs, and POSIX socket APIs (connect, getsockopt, errno, sockaddr, AF_INET/AF_INET6, socklen_t) — POSIX library calls are platform APIs, not compiler language extensions, so they are not in scope for MISRA Rule 1.2 as stated. The macros shown (OS_CHECK_POINTER, OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET) use ordinary macro expressions and address-of operations; they do not rely on compiler-specific extensions. Conditional compilation (#ifdef OS_NETWORK_SUPPORTS_IPV6) is standard preprocessor usage. Therefore there are no code fragments in the supplied code that warrant investigation for use of compiler language extensions under MISRA C 2023 Rule 1.2.
